headline: Hey Blondie - m4w
body_text: I doubt you'll ever see this, perhaps this will be lost among the thousands of other lost souls seeking the fleeting moments of peace barely beyond their grasp... but if I am to have any faith in destiny, I gotta say what I have to say... here.We were children in high school, not as experienced in the world, but nevertheless, of our 4 years, I regret I only got to spend one with you. We were never together, but the few moments we spent across from each other, they seemed magical to me, even though I always messed with you... since the first time we were stuck in that room by the cafeteria trying to solve a murder involving dolls and fake blood, to the last time we were stuck in that room full of biology textbooks, trying to organize the shelves for a strange man... I treasured every moment I spent with you. This December you will be 23, and we'll have been apart for 5 years... yet, I see you in my dreams as though it were yesterday.Towards the end of the school year, 5 years ago, I realized what I felt for you, your friend told me you felt the same way, and yet every time you drew near me, I pulled away because of what I believed in... Honor, Loyalty... to this moment I am bound by that code, which is why I never had to courage to see you again... But that doesn't stop me from feeling the warmth of your soul in my dreams... I see you just an arm's length away, and my heart burns to embrace you, and tell you how much you mean to me, how much you've always meant to me... My Blondie, I wonder if you still have those little notes I'd pass you throughout class... last time we spoke, 2 years later, you said you did, but I made such a terrible impression on you, that perhaps what you must have felt for me, has slipped away into the chaos of the forgotten... You probably don't even remember me, probably for the best, because the truth is, I don't deserve you... You were the sweetest, most beautiful friend, and I never even had the courage to take your hand and tell you that I love you... and when I finally did, you disappeared... because what value is the love of a man you cant even see? What value is the love of a man bound by a code of honor which could never let us be one? For that reason, my dearest Blondie, not a moment goes by, that I don't hope that you find love, and happiness with someone amazing, someone who could do right by you, someone who could keep you warm and safe in the coldest and darkest hours... My love for you will never fade, and my heart will forever be in chains, because I could never let you go... Forever yours,M.S.

headline: Truely Missed - m4w
body_text: It is another late night for myself, 1:59 in the morning and all I can do to pass the time is read personals here on Craigslist. Time to time I actually find a genuine heart felt attempt to find that lost connection. Most of the rest, lustful yearning for sexual satisfaction. I feel it's high time for a post of my own.A missed connection, a missed romance, a missed love. I am 29 now and still have dreams of her. We were best friends in high school, my ride or die chick. Back then we were so innocent and naive. Neither one of use truely knew nor understood the complexities of life. Day in day out all we ever did was hang out with one another and sure we did have our own crew of friends as well. With each bond to one another just as strong as the next. Couple of my friends had huge crushes on you; make any situation between us off limits. I was to loyal to "cock block" a another friend. On most nights when we all crahed at one house we'd find each other through the passed out bodies sprawled across the floor just to snuggle with one another. Most of the the time it ended in me slowy taking your shirt off and senualy rubing your beaufiul body down. There definitely was a connection, stronge connection. But knowing how much chaos it would cause we; maybe I just say "I", never acted. We had so much fun together. There was a lot of love between us.As time passed through high school we met our "first loves". Honestly in the end I dont think it worked out for either one of us. As youngings you live and you learn. I never gave much thought to the future for the simple reason, I thought you would always be there. You were my best friend. I know now it was my fault you left. During that last year of school and many more years after, doing and saling drugs became my life. I guess you must have seen to much of what drugs could do growing up? Knowing now and looking back at life, its never nice to see a friend on drugs let a alone a best friend. You had every right to walk away and never look back.It took till my early 20's to kick the habit and distance myself from everyone. I had a failure of a 5 year long relationship. For the first time in a long time I could see the world with open eyes. And guess who I saw, you! It had been a long time, sorry that it wasn't for a better reason. Our good friend had passed away from cancer. There was so much I wanted to say, so much I wanted to show you. But time had made us strangers to one another. It was your memory of losing you that helped me in the end stop all the dealing and doing of drugs. I never want to lose a bond, a conection that we shared with such strength ever again. You tought me more about lose, then I could have ever learned in a book. In return you made me a stronger man.Even if I would have married the woman I was with for 5 years, it would have never lasted. The simple reason is, I know whats out there. The love, the bond, the connection that ran as deep as ours did is worth finding again in life, even if I have to wait till I'm a old man. I see so many of our brother and sisters out there only focusing on the sexual appetite of the body, and not the love of the soul. There are days when I wish I could share the feeling of love that I have (had) , so that more people could understand the love is real.If I could have my best friend back, I would love her and only her till my last dieing breather. Stay by her side weather she had a disease or missing limb. Whatever she wanted or needed, I would do anything within my power to try and achieve it for her. She would be my world as I would be hers.The sorrow I feel in my heart these days is a constant reminder. She'll never read this nor will I ever see her again. But, through her actions she made a young boy grow into a man who knows how to treat a woman right. A man that knows how to love a woman for more then just her body. A man who simple knows, right from wrong! I am no poet and this story is far from a novel, but I just wanted to share something real with you the reader. I hope that this story will help you to know that your not alone in this world. After all we are only human!Till I see you again in my dreams,

body_text: ...so this is crazy posting a missed connection (but I suppose, that's the nature of virtually all postings of missed connections), but I keep thinking about the girl I crossed paths with tonight at the Barnes and Noble on 3rd Avenue at 54th, in Midtown East. It had been a long day, but with the weather as perfect as it is I knew it would feel criminal to spend the night at home in my apartment. I went out for a walk around the neighborhood, then off to the bookstore for a bit and while in the latter I came across that smile of yours and it immediately changed everything. I was walking one way, you were headed toward me, and you had this beaming smile that filled me with the greatest feeling; I absolutely could not take my eyes off you. Then to my surprise, you not only kept smiling while looking at me but said "hi." (I was surprised because I was dressed like such a scrub tonight! I had figured I was just going on a walk and certainly wasn't expecting to cross paths with someone like you.)It took me off guard that I just squeaked out saying "hey there," and kept walking, not fully registering what had just happened. My plan right before that was to run a few more errands, so that part of my brain kept the plan in motion as I wandered out the store. My feet had me headed toward CVS, while my heart kept yelling, "Turn around! Go back and talk to her!" I really should have listened to that advice, but clearly that wasn't the case so now I'm on craigslist of all places, typing away with fingers crossed. Maybe, hopefully, and hoping some more!

headline: Steven....

headline: Bar Car on the Amtrak Empire Svc Line October 19, 2015 - w4m
body_text: This afternoon the most handsome man I've ever seen briefly shared a table with me in the bar car of the Empire Service line on Amtrak (leaving Penn Station at 1:20 pm). He was so sublime that if I could have found the courage to gaze at him for more than 30 seconds I am convinced my weakening eyesight might be perfectly restored.He was presumedly British (accent) but relieved of the upped-ness of that culture. This I know by the fact that he was snacking on a bag of Doritos - something that is beneath most Brits I know. When he asked to join me to eat his sandwich and "smelly" chips the only comment I could craft reeked of 2nd grade snark, "Of course you can as long as you don't lick your fingers." No, eager reader, this gracious man did not lick his fingers in between chips, nor did he lick them while eating his sandwich. In fact he cut and ate his panini with a knife and fork. He sandwich carving skills were exceptional. This ability is very dear to me having disappointingly watched so many men hold their cutting fork in their fist like a Neanderthal. (Thank you to my dad for hours of training at Johnny's Steakhouse.)Sigh. This beautiful beau had a gentle disposition but hinted at his twisted humor when he breathed, "Saved for the time being!" after a mother and little girl decided not to share our lunch table. I joked about making our aura's really big to keep all the tykes at bay. (God save me from my alt lifestyle/aura talk.)His hair was brown and thick and wavy like a young Billy Cruddup - but richer - more like that new hot guy on Grey's Anatomy whose name escapes me. His hands were thick and manly. Really not an inch of him seemed overly delicate like so many of the British lads these days. If there was a question about the existence of a rugged Brit I can confirm the sighting of one today (though maybe he was an Aussie or S. African!).His chin blushed a deep dusty rose when he spoke to me. (This truth I can only verify from the peripheral vision in my left eye as I could not bring myself to look at him head on out of fear I might simply disappear from this human existence having seen all things that need to be seen in this life.)It's true I'm insanely shy in these situations and I could barely bring myself to converse with him. Such moments are beyond painful. In fact I've never felt such agony as that of my throat being clasped close in such moments by some unseen hand with fierce strength.After he finished eating and scrolling through his iPhone (white with no cover - clearly confident it would never be at risk to be dropped and broken as he obviously handles all beautiful things carefully), he thanked me and returned to his seat in rear car. "Yes, take your big aura and go." I said (Seriously now God - what will become of me with such doomed verbal crafting skills? Curses!)My assigned seat was back in the same car as his. Who knows, since I'd never gotten beyond the bar car, possibly it was right next to him. But I could not find the courage to go and see. Woe woe woe, did I spite fate?After he left, I was swarmed by the ladies who regularly commute upstate and hang to work along the way in the bar car. 'That never happens." they said. "Never in my 10 years of commuting." they said. Never has such gift from the Gods set across from them in all their journeys. They all painfully watched my inability to pick up the ball. They tried sending me good vibes and all saw their younger selves in me and hoped I could find it inside to rise to the occasion. One woman claimed she'd never seen a man so obviously interested to talk to a woman. Obvious to all, it seemed but me. We laughed loudly and talked even more loudly about every detail (of nothing) of every moment (of more actual nothingness) that transpired. Describing in detail every inch of him that could be seen. Sigh. Such laughs with such fine empathetic ladies.Finally, in Albany all of us in the bar car were banished to their seats by the new conductor on board. A chance, I hoped, to find an excuse to speak to him who is mine and unnamed. But he was already gone. Did he get off the train in Croton, Poughkeepsie, Rhinecliff or Hudson? I don't know.Were any of those stops his home or does he live in NYC and will a chance meeting as unplanned as this one be possible again in the future? I don't know. Does Tinder's new paid feature enable me to swipe in various cities along the Hudson till I find him again? I don't know.With despair and relief entwined I settled into my seat only to became regretfully aware of the acoustics between the bar and last car from which he was now absent. Like that strange spot in the Senate hall in DC where even a whisper can be heard clearly across the room it seemed every single word in even the most casual conversation spoken in the bar car was now amplified. I need not worry about all words stuck in my throat when he was near.Everything sounds great in the car next to the bar car.‪#‎missedconnection‬ ‪#‎amtrak‬ ‪#‎doritoman‬ ‪#‎madforkandknifeskills‬ ‪#‎ruggedbrit‬ ‪#‎shygirl‬ ‪#‎memoir‬

headline: Bad Feminist - m4w
body_text: This is not so much a "missed connection" but rather a lament that I am missing the connection. Our connection. It happened suddenly, this connection, but I feel changed for it, grateful, and so am willing to take to the pages of craigslist in an overtly and overly romantic hope that you'll look here too. It occurred in that fleeting moment as I was leaving the Downtown 6 train in which our eyes locked and my bashful smile was returned to me, transformed, radiant. Or maybe you were smirking at the book I was reading, a veritable tourist map for navigating the modern woman. Regardless, for that fleeting moment I felt perhaps my self, me, in my used steel workers jacket, banal jeans and leather boots, hair parted, beard just now starting to grow in again, were enough. I first saw you standing on the platform at 59th street, reading something on your phone, lost in the infinite expanse of your own inner world, the mind behind the pretty glasses. You were wearing mostly shades of black in a immaculately assembled outfit, yet a motif comprised of accents tinged with brown suggested the sweetness of chocolate. The black jacket just slightly overhanging the black skirt. The two black-tighted legs stretching up, to the heavens, to my heaven, to grace. Redemption. When you shifted your weight from one leg to the next your coat would open and reveal a grey sweater that betrayed the soft outline of your breast. I am well aware of the damage wrought by the male gaze. I try to avoid propagating it. I try to stop myself. Especially for you. And yet.The way the sharp edges of your glasses compliment your high cheekbones, matching the brown highlights in your hair, (hair so perfectly glossy, so rich, whose photograph really should grace the boxes of care products in fashionable boutiques, mind you) all reveal an eye for detail and arrangement that can only be accompanied by profound intelligence, strength, and independence. A depth of personhood too rich for base objectification. Sexualization. And yet. I try not to look at you too often. Try no to drink too deeply from the sight of you. Try not to imagine what it would feel like to wrap my arm inside, between your coat and sweatered waist. Try not to objectify. To project onto you qualities of sensitivity and sensuality that may not be there. Try not to imagine the kids we could have. Your scent. Your taste. Attempt not to gauge what your weight would feel in my arms, holding you against a wall, your arms around my neck. How soft your lips must be. The delicate tongue behind your white teeth. Your laugh. And yet. Until that moment, that connection, a smile parried, I hated myself a bit. I ogled. I fantasized. I felt every bit the title of my book, Bad Feminist. And then you smiled and all was right in the world.
